metadata.case_name: Appellants v. General Manager, Bengal Nagpur Railway

facts.text: Appellant employed in 1939 in Bengal Nagpur Railway as clerk in workshop at Nagpur.
In 1946, State took over administration of Railway; gave option to employees to continue on terms in document dated July 5, 1946; appellant accepted and continued.
Governor-General promulgated Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949 under ss. 241, 247, 266 of Government of India Act, 1935; came into force May 14, 1949.
July 6, 1950: General Manager issued notice under R.3 of Security Rules stating reason to believe appellant engaged in subversive activities; called to show cause; placed under suspension.

Notice under R.3 recited appellant reasonably suspected member and office secretary of B.N. Rly. Workers' Union (Communist sponsored), associated with communists, attended private meetings, agitated for general strike Nov 1948-Jan 1949 to paralyse communication.
July 29, 1950: Appellant sent explanation denying allegations.
September 8, 1950: Committee of Advisers held enquiry, heard appellant, found charges true.
April 3, 1951: General Manager terminated services under R.3 with prior approval of President, giving one month's salary in lieu of notice.
February 3, 1951: Appellant filed writ petition in Nagpur High Court challenging notice of July 6, 1950 and suspension; amended to challenge termination order.
November 16, 1951: Nagpur High Court dismissed writ petitions, holding orders sustainable under R.148(3) and (4) of Railway Establishment Code even if Security Rules invalid.
Facts in companion appeals (CAs 47 and 48 of 1956) similar.
Appellants are non-pensionable railway servants liable to termination on notice under R.148(3) Railway Establishment Code.
Clause 10 of service agreement dated July 5, 1946: For matters not specifically dealt with, Railway rules applicable to persons appointed on or after Oct 1, 1946 apply; discharge one such matter.

legal_issues.text: Whether the orders terminating the services of the appellants can be upheld under R. 148 of the Railway Establishment Code
Whether the Security Rules are bad as infringing a) Art. 14, b) Art. 19(1)(c) and c) Art. 311 of the Constitution
Whether the impugned orders are not valid, even according to the Security Rules
Whether those orders were not passed by the competent authorities

petitioner_arguments.text: Ground on which High Court judgment proceeds (R.148) not put forward by respondents in pleadings and should not have been allowed.
Security Rules in contravention of Arts. 14, 19(1)(c) and 311; orders void.
Even if Security Rules valid, orders not justified; not made by competent authorities.
Classification based on 'subversive activities' vague, undefined, includes lawful activities like trade unionism; unreasonable under Art.14.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14; Anwar Ali Sarkar; Ananthanarayanan v. Southern Railway

petitioner_arguments.text: Action because Communists/trade unionists; denies freedom of association under Art.19(1)(c).
Procedure under Security Rules does not satisfy Art.311.
Charges relate to events prior to May 14, 1949; retrospective operation not warranted.

respondent_arguments.text: Security Rules valid; orders not open to attack.
Orders sustainable under R.148(3),(4) Railway Establishment Code as appellants non-pensionable servants paid one month's pay.
Power under R.3 Security Rules not different from R.148; reference to service agreement makes it under R.148.
Security Rules protect employees; if procedure not followed, order bad, but R.148 not invocable then.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Security Rules; Sambandam v. General Manager; Prasadi v. Works Manager

court_reasoning.text: Authorities acted only under Security Rules; notice, procedure, orders recite R.3; respondents never pleaded R.148; cannot sustain under R.148 as Security Rules independent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Orders purportedly under Security Rules; cannot be shunted to R.148 without convincing reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Security Rules form self-contained code for special class; reference to service agreement only for notice period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If interpretation equates to R.148, rules serve no purpose.

court_reasoning.text: Proceed on basis orders under R.3 Security Rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondents agree to determine validity under Security Rules.

court_reasoning.text: 'Subversive activities' in context of national security precise; classification valid under Art.14; not vague.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Persons reasonably suspected of subversive activities prejudicial to national security form distinct class.

court_reasoning.text: Action not because Communist/trade unionist but for subversive activities; no infringement of Art.19(1)(c).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No fundamental right to continued employment.

court_reasoning.text: Termination under R.3 not dismissal/removal under Art.311; no premature termination or loss of accrued benefits; like discharge under R.148.
Rules prospective; antecedents used to infer future likelihood; not retrospective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Materials from past conduct do not make operation retrospective.

holdings.text: Orders cannot be upheld under R.148 as purportedly under Security Rules which are independent.
Security Rules not repugnant to Art.14; valid classification based on subversive activities prejudicial to national security.
Termination under R.3 not dismissal/removal; Art.311 inapplicable.
Security Rules constitutional; orders valid thereunder.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14 classification; special courts for speedy trial invalid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Budhan Choudhry v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles of valid classification under Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Not every termination is dismissal under Art.311.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.311 applies only to punitive dismissals.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi
Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: What amounts to punishment/dismissal under Art.311: premature termination or loss of benefits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sambandam v. General Manager, I. Ry.
precedents_cited.relevance: If Security Rules procedure not followed, order bad; R.148 not applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Security Rules challenged as violating equality, freedom of association, dismissal safeguards; certificate for appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for termination; procedure; compensation; upheld as valid.

statutes_cited.name: Railway Establishment Code, Volume I
statutes_cited.relevance: General termination on notice for non-pensionable servants; not applicable here.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held Security Rules constitutional, not violating Arts.14,19(1)(c),311; orders terminating services valid under R.3 thereof; appeals against High Court dismissal rejected.

key_quotes.text: "a member of the Railway Service who, in the opinion of the competent authority is engaged in or is reasonably suspected to be engaged in subversive activities... may be compulsorily retired... if his retention... prejudicial to national security."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of R.3 Security Rules central to case.

key_quotes.text: "the words subversive activities in the context of national security are sufficiently precise in their import to sustain a valid classification."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The order terminating the services under R. 3 of the Security Rules stands on the same footing as an order of discharge under R. 148, and it is neither one of dismissal nor of removal within the meaning of Art. 311."
key_quotes.speaker: court
